chapter.title: Extending the software model

note.para: Support for the software model is currently incubating. Please be aware that the DSL, APIs and other configuration may change in later Gradle versions.

chapter.para: This chapter describes how to extend the Gradle software model just like how the Java, Play Framework and Native support do. Before reading this you should be familiar with the Gradle software model rule based configuration and concepts.

chapter.para: The rest of this chapter is dedicated to explaining what is going on behind this build script.

section.title: Concepts
section.para: A custom software model type has a public type, a base interface and internal views. Multiple such types then collaborate to define a custom software model.

section.title: Public type and base interfaces
section.para: Extended types declare a public type that extends a base interface:

itemizedlist.listitem: Source sets extend the base interface

section.para: The public type is exposed to build logic.

section.title: Internal views
section.para: Adding internal views to your model type, you can make some data visible to build logic via a public type, while hiding the rest of the data behind the internal view types.

section.title: The component -> binary -> task chain
section.para: Components generate binaries. Binaries are built by tasks. You write rules to generate both binaries from components and tasks from binaries.

section.title: About internal views
section.para: Internal views can be added to an already registered type or to a new custom type. In other words, using internal views, you can attach extra properties to already registered component, binary and source set types like JvmLibrarySpec, JarBinarySpec or JavaSourceSet and to the custom types you write.
